review_title: Frustrating bureaucracy kills the joy of work
pros: There are great researchers at NTU, and people are willing to take risks, try new ideas. Students are also hard-working and ambitious, which makes for a fast-moving, happening environment.
cons: Finance and procurement actively put hurdles that slow down research. The departments are very slow, ill managed (people take leaves without any substitutes). The departments are very hierarchical: if you are not a professor, they will waste your time by asking you for all sorts of documents for your reimbursement. If you ask questions, they will parrot policy rather than actually address the question: a sign that these people just want to protect themselves rather than support the researchers. Every interaction with the bureaucracy requires two tries. The first one is ignored by the bureaucracy. The second one (hopefully) is responded to, maybe several weeks laters. On top of that, the university celebrates that it is 120th in employee satisfaction - as if that is something to celebrate.

pros: Can't think of any pros for it.
cons: The turnover rate here is high precisely because of the management. I worked at HELIOS and it was the biggest mistake coming here. So many full time staff and locums have quit, a lot of people cannot tolerate it. The higher-ups do not trust you and make it a point to micromanage everything. They are all very scared of the PI here and scared of their direct bosses. The manager is straight-up unprofessional and extremely rude & petty to the staff especially to the ones they don't like. Discriminatory treatment is a regular thing. It's a dead-end job with no progression, good for retiring or working ad hoc. Workplace is toxic, politics aplenty, terrible staff welfare. Always do things last minute then blame staff because they never prepare beforehand. Lunch is only 45 mins and they keep track so even though they give you a kopitiam card to use you can't actually use it for daily lunch bc it's a long walk to the food court. Overall a very stressful and toxic environment that lacks respect for your time and lacks boundaries because of work messages after working hours end. The PI is aware of the bad attitude of our boss but doesn't do anything about it because collecting data > staff concerns. The management like to bring up sob stories of staying back late on weekends to make us feel guilty. Taking leave is so troublesome because they came up with a quota per day of how many people can be absent. The team lead also don't know how to lead, wait until something bad happens then will start to think of preventive measures. Even HR cannot do anything about all of this. Some of us had to pay for equipment and training using our own money first which is a red flag.

review_title: Decent base pay. Horrible bonus scheme. Good work flexibility arrangement. Good employee benefits. Flat hierarchy
pros:
NTU research staff typically offer a decent base salary scheme. 

Flat hierarchy system allow most teams to gain flexiblity to work from home  even during the post-pandemic period. When done correctly, these schemes in fact result in a productivity boost and avoids peak hour travel time.

The perfect work location for part-time students looking to upgrade themselves while gaining work experience.

School ranking will very like to rise in foreseeable future
cons:
Overwhelmed majority of the post-grad research staff are foreign talents. HR is mostly females. If you are a Singaporean male, it may be awkward and embarrassing to take a 1 week NS leave for your annual reservist commitment as chances are you are properly the only Singaporean male with NS commitment in the team.

The bonus scheme is vague and almost non-existence. Therefore the net remuneration package is often less attractive than other research institutions, or what you can achieve among the western counterparts.
E.g: 13months bonus provided by the company has bizarre rules such as New hires on their first year are not entitled 13 month bonus or any prorated among from date of joining

review_title: Tons of Red Tapes and Political with no Senses
pros:
Yearly increment if your reporting officer is willing to rate your performance meet expectation or above.
Decent working place and environment.
cons:
Management is self-prestige driven which often unconsciously neglect of facts which can lead to deadly decisions or time waste.

Management wants extra amount of control without dirtying their hands, workload will unlimitedly get pushed down.

Tons of red tapes across departments which often will stuck a simple task and get workers caught in between.

Generally, a lot of staffs maintain a self-saving "Clean Hands" mentality. If you found a helper in this company, cherish him/her. Because this won't last long.

If you are thinking that with good attitude, honest, hardworking, good results will gets you a promotion, please lower your assumption on this will surely makes you happier and go longer. Favoritism is everywhere in this company. Long years of service staffs ends up getting nothing but ONLY workload, but non-experience new staff without good KPIs can get into the under the table "Grooming-List".

cons:
1. Cannot understand why administrative procedures are getting more bureaucratic.
2. Wonder why when companies are encouraged to adopt flexi-work arrangement and hybrid working arrangement, the company still insist on 100% in-office work model. Seems like there is an inherent distrust in their own staff and cannot stand seeing "empty offices" even after 2.5 years of Covid-19 situation. Shows low adaptability and stubbornness of management.
3. Shortage of manpower is so bad that once someone goes on leave, the work will be stuck for as long as the person is not around, can be stuck for months.
4. Career progression is next to zero.

pros:
1. Good benefits for Staff:
(a) Annual and other leave is sufficient
(b) Medical care for family (if you add in your Flexiben) but need co-pay ($5 for GP)
(c) Various passes to local attractions
(d) CReW planned activities for Staff

2. Good work-life balance (for some offices) but seemingly changing (see con)
cons:
1. No career progression and very slow promotion (but some Staff can get promoted yearly, depending on bosses' preference, may not be because of performance)
2. Stagnant pay
3. Unprofessional HR practices (e.g. salary market adjustment, increase only for Staff with pay below median within their rank pay scale)
4. Top heavy (too many management level Staff)
5. No clear leadership from top, Townhall used to blow own trumpet and is Mushroom Management
6. IT systems are outdated and CITS leadership do not really know how to improve but only to change to off-the-shelf systems (but these are unable to fit the organisation's goals)
6. KPI - (a) must look good (priority) on the outside and (b) cut cost
7. Headcount freeze, difficult to get replacement. Hence work-life balance started to get affected.
8. Low morale, many long service Staff left

pros:

Very poor bonus and increment. People who did less and are less capable may get more bonus than you. Not transparent how they allocate. 

Many dinosaurs (in mindset) who are reluctant to adopt tech solutions even though IT makes it available, or if other more junior staff push for it. Also many dinosaurs in terms of flexible work arrangements, hybrid or wfh.

Campus amenities are very crowded. 

Cleanliness can be better, especially for toilets.

job_title: PhD Student in Tampines New Town,
pros: Nice campus, great facilities. The staff is helpful with exception of the finance department which operates in chaos. The are many resources to work in cutting-edge technologies.
cons: Terrible work-life balance culture. The campus is amazing beautiful but people don't have the time to enjoy it. The finance department is painfully slow for everything, from purchasing to money reimbursement. Equipments cost less at night or during weekends at some facilities so the PIs push people to work at night and on weekends to save money . If something goes wrong with your PhD and you consider to quit, they will ask you to pay them about 9500 sgd per semester you were enrolled in.

job_title: Assistant Director of Communications in Singapore
pros: Management is always changing, so there is leadership renewal and new ideas. Leave gets more as you stay longer with the company, up to 28 days per year. Training opportunities are available with subsidised Master degree courses available (with bond of 3 years). Opportunities to execute new projects and initiatives are welcome. Recession-proof industry with no retrenchment.
cons: HR expects you to overperform beyond expectations and prove you are capable of leadership before promotion. Pay increments are given out only to those graded to meet expectations and are meagre at best, not even meeting inflation rate. The longer you stay at a current position, the more your salary is decreasing thanks to inflation rate. There is little incentive to promote people as they prefer to hire from external organisations who are perceived to be better.

review_title: Singaporeans should not join this university to work or study!
pros: a lot of leave days
cons:
Ever since NTU dropped in some university ranking standards, NTU has been hiring A LOT of foreigners as professors and researchers since 2008 just to game the university rankings system! (Google fake rolex and NTU and you will know what i mean) Some foreigner professors and researchers are very arrogant and disrespectful of local laws and regulations such as the COVID 19 act. They typically run research centers horribly. Most professors have no experience in running research centres. Researchers working in such centres have poor welfare and HR are just paper tigers, seems not to care about about this and just leave everything to the centre directors whose management style is subpar. Their fundamental research has typically low research impact. 

To end off, Singaporeans please do not join NTU to work in admin or as researchers or study! You will be better off in other universities!
